ProtonVPN is a VPN provider that utilizes the OpenVPN and WireGuard protocol.

sections.title: OpenVPN
sections.content: Install the openvpn package, then follow the OpenVPN setup.

sections.title: WireGuard
sections.content: Install the wireguard-tools package. Ensure systemd-resolvconf is also installed. Then follow the WireGuard setup.

sections.title: Official ProtonVPN client
sections.content:
Install proton-vpn-gtk-app - the latest GTK version.

You must also use NetworkManager and install network-manager-applet, otherwise the VPN will not connect. You can still use your current network manager, although running multiple network managers is not recommended.

sections.title: OpenVPN setup
sections.content:
Download one or more OpenVPN configuration files from ProtonVPN Downloads page.

Copy the *.ovpn client configuration files into /etc/openvpn/client/ and make backup of original.

Follow OpenVPN#The update-systemd-resolved custom script to make sure that all your network traffic uses VPN (Note: The steps mention a client.conf file, which corresponds to the *.ovpn files.) If you use systemd older than 229, follow OpenVPN#The update-resolv-conf custom script.

For usage instructions, see Using OpenVPN.

sections.title: WireGuard setup
sections.content:
Download WireGuard configuration files by signing into ProtonVPN and go to Downloads → WireGuard configuration.

Move the .conf files into /etc/wireguard. Consider renaming the .conf files if necessary as WireGuard might not work well with names that are too long.

If you have not already, start/enable systemd-resolved.

sections.title: Using OpenVPN
sections.content:
Connect to the VPN:

```
# openvpn /etc/openvpn/client/client_config_file.ovpn
```

Provide OpenVPN / IKEv2 Username from the ProtonVPN Account page.

Press Ctrl+c to close the VPN connection.

sections.title: Using WireGuard
sections.content:
To add and bring up an interface, replace CONFIG_FILE with the configuration file, e.g. /etc/wireguard/wgnet0.conf:

```
# wg-quick up CONFIG_FILE
```

To check the status of the connection, run

```
# wg
```

To tear down and remove the interface:

```
# wg-quick down CONFIG_FILE
```

sections.title: Enable VPN on boot
sections.content: For systemd service configuration, see OpenVPN#systemd service configuration.

sections.title: Only run certain applications through VPN with network namespaces
sections.content: vopono supports automatic configuration file generation for ProtonVPN, and allows you to run applications inside temporary network namespaces so only those run through the VPN.

sections.title: Save login information
sections.content:
To retain VPN credentials for subsequent connections, create the following file with your own login information on two lines and place it in the directory where you will run the startup script listed above.

```
username
password
```

Then add the line auth-user-pass login.conf to any relevant *.ovpn files.

sections.title: SysTray/Indicator
sections.content: For the system/tray indicator to work, ensure you have installed libappindicator-gtk3 and gnome-shell-extension-appindicator.

sections.title: Prevent IPv6 leaks
sections.content: ProtonVPN's servers default to using the IPv6 internet protocol with their official Linux client. If IPv6 leaks are observed, you can prevent them by blocking IPv6 traffics or disabling IPv6. See IPv6#Disable IPv6.

sections.title: Enable Port Forwarding
sections.content:
For paid ProtonVPN users, port forwarding can be enabled.

- For proton-vpn-gtk-app it is supported as a setting. When enabled, the forwarded port will be displayed when you connect to a server.
- For OpenVPN and Wireguard installations, refer to ProtonVPN's documentation to enable port forwarding.

sections.title: Official client will not connect
sections.content:
You may see an error message like “Unknown reason occurred.” when attempting to connect.

Install NetworkManager (and configure if needed) then install network-manager-applet. Both need to be running for ProtonVPN official clients to connect, whether you are using the GUI or CLI application.
